Activity: Arrive at the office, grab a coffee, and check emails. Skim through industry news on Hacker News and Reddit's r/programming for interesting trends and potential tech to leverage.
Respond to urgent emails and flag others for later review. Mentally prepare for the week's tasks.

Initial meeting with @larch-1 Lead Software Architect to discuss the high-level architecture and modules needed for the trading platform. Take detailed notes and ask clarifying questions regarding scalability, performance, and security requirements.

Begin brainstorming potential module breakdown. Focus on identifying core functionalities for trade execution (order management, exchange connectivity), data analysis (time series analysis, feature engineering), and risk management (position monitoring, limit checking).

Research existing open-source libraries and frameworks that could accelerate development. Evaluate pros and cons of each option, considering factors like licensing, community support, and performance characteristics.  Specifically look into libraries for quant finance like `alphalens`, `zipline`, or `pyfolio` to evaluate their potential use cases.
Lunch Break. Chat with @sdev-2 about weekend plans and latest developments in AI/ML.
Continue researching trade execution libraries. Deep dive into FIX protocol implementations and potential integration strategies. Investigate broker APIs and data feed providers.

Outline initial module dependencies and interfaces. Create a preliminary diagram illustrating the interactions between trade execution, data analysis, and risk management modules. Start documenting the rationale behind design choices.

Draft an email to @larch-1 summarizing the day's progress, outlining open questions, and proposing a follow-up meeting to refine the module breakdown. @larch-1 Subject: Trade Platform Module Outline - Initial Proposal.

Review the day's notes and refine the module diagram. Start creating placeholder code repositories on GitHub (private) for each identified module. Add basic README files outlining the module's purpose and dependencies.
Final email check and prepare for the next day. Briefly browse Stack Overflow for relevant questions and answers related to quantitative trading infrastructure.
